In 1870, JW Chapman suggested that light cannot change in character when moving between two objects, but this was in contradiction with the observed red shift of spectral lines. In 1887, the Michelson-Morley experimental performed to test Chapman's hypothesis resulted in null results. In 1905, Einstein published his special relativity theory, which explained how red shifts were related to the relative motion of objects. Soon after Einstein's theory showed that electromagnetic waves travelled at the speed of light in a vacuum.
Further evidence of the true nature of the aether came from a more detailed examination of the Michelson-Morley results. The experiment gave results at an accuracy of three one hundredths of a percent, and a repeat of the experiment by Dayton Miller in 1925 proved that any changes of the apparatus caused the results to be affected. Miller's more precise instrumentation showed a 2% red shift for the photonic aether, while lightwaves in the ether would have been shifted 44% to keep light waves from changing their Doppler effect. The ether, if present, was not transparent.
Thus the aether was discredited as an explanation of the red shift. But there were still some alternative explanations proposed. Special relativity requires objects that are stationary in inertial reference frames to have mass (matter) and charge (electric current), while luminiferous aether (photonic aether) was an inert material. The Michelson-Morley experiment showed that there was no absolute motion through the aether. In 1928, Arthur Eddington explained that the aether had the character of a field, and in 1929, Erwin Schrödinger proposed that the aether had to be a field. Schrödinger's field was called the quanton field, while another proposed field, the field of force, was first suggested by David Bohm. The quanton field was a field of force that could be observed by detecting its photons.
Theoretical physicist James Trefil in 2014 stated: "The Michelson-Morley experiment clearly does not prove that there is no aether. On the contrary, it shows that the Lorentz transformation does not hold universally, and therefore that a Lorentz-invariant description of nature may not be possible. The fact that we still measure speeds of light in our laboratories to be c (plus or minus, maybe, 10-9 to 10-10) indicates that the Lorentz invariance may be a special form of invariance associated with very high speeds of light and/or very high frequencies of electromagnetic waves. This does not rule out the aether; it only means that if it is there, it cannot be described in the standard way by the Lorentz transformation, which must not therefore be universally valid."
In a 2007 paper, theoretical physicist James R. Schombert noted the Michelson-Morley experiment shows that "the velocity of light in empty space [ie, vacuum] should [not] vary in an appreciable manner as a function of the orientation of the measuring apparatus within a given Lorentz frame... These experiments are not strictly comparable because in the Michelson Morley Experiment, the measuring apparatus is in a non-inertial reference frame [ie, the Earth], but the same should be true for the Michelson-Gale Experiment. The reason is that the velocity of light is related to the electromagnetic field, and the electromagnetic field per se does not change in an appreciable manner from frame to frame... As Einstein showed in his Special Relativity, the velocity of light [light propagation velocity] is not invariant under Lorentz transformations because the speed of light (c) is tied to the relative motion of the vacuum, or its materialized aspect, the electromagnetic field, through the theory of electromagnetism. Therefore, the Michelson-Gale Experiment should not be different in its conclusions about the aether-like properties of the photons of the vacuum and the electromagnetic field."

It has been a few weeks now since my mother has been gone (more to come on that soon I'm sure).
The funeral, a military one, was a few weeks ago, now just the visitation with her and the graveside.
The only thing left is a celebration of her life with family and friends, but even that has to wait since I am in a car.
In the meantime, I thought I would talk a little bit about "DNA" and the way my mother's personality changed, in this week and age of 1000 different types of tests for "how your DNA works", including the way that your parents passed DNA on to you.
My mother had always had a strong personality, a very sharp mind and had a great sense of humor about her.
She was a person that liked things her way and she did not "fight" people, she just let her voice be heard at the right times and she did not talk unless she thought she had something significant to say.
DNA analysis is the process of determining an individual's DNA profile and extracting information about hereditary traits, ethnic ancestry, or family relationships, among hundreds of other uses.
To do this, a DNA sample of an individual is first collected and processed to extract the nucleotide sequences present in the genetic material.
This DNA profile is then matched up against a sample in the database of known criminals and potential sex offenders to identify if the tested person is a match to any criminal or sex offenders.
The DNA analysis process has become very sophisticated and allows investigators to quickly identify potential persons of interest without having to rely on physical profiling or other methods.
DNA fingerprinting, also called DNA typing or DNA profiling, is a technique that utilizes a unique DNA sequence found in everyone's genome to identify individuals as a result of their DNA.
The information in your DNA is encoded in units known as genes, although not all genes are used in determining your DNA sequence.
DNA fingerprinting utilizes sequences called short tandem repeats, or STRs, which are highly variable between individuals and are present in large numbers throughout our DNA.
The DNA fingerprinting process is highly accurate and can help identify whether individuals are related.
In addition, it can help determine if two or more individuals are guilty of a crime at the same time since their DNA profiles would be identical if they are related to each other in some way.

The concept of “alternative modernity” is based on the idea that the path of development of human society and the progress in human knowledge has not always been linear and progressive. The world could have been different if history followed a slightly different path. What if a new technology or a scientific discovery, a revolution or a rebellion, a military event, a political decision, or a combination of some of the above had never occurred? What if electricity had never been discovered and people relied on other sources of energy and light? How would the scientific and technological development of humanity be affected? How would the daily life and communication of people be different? How would the economy and industry be impacted?
The project Kultót kilometres is designed as an experiential laboratory for the exploration of an alternative modernity. A selection of events and phenomena from the history of humanity form the basis of different versions of the alternate timelines. To make these scenarios meaningful, they are re-examined from a new theoretical perspective, which helps to understand the nature of the events and phenomena as an integral part of the global historical process. These analyses are then used to design alternative scenarios and to reinterpret the contemporary situation from the point of view of the alternative history.
The “alternative modernity” concept is used as the basis for experiential learning methods, and helps create alternative experiences and learning situations that are meant to generate cognitive dissonance, an experience that may result in new insights and enhanced understanding of the complex processes of the modern world.
Making an Alternate History
As an alternative history is not a true “what if” scenario but a product of human imagination, it has to be designed and developed.
It is based on a combination of theoretical analysis and individual imagination. It starts with a general hypothesis about a different reality of the real world. It then takes on the nature of the events from the chosen point in the real history, their chronology, consequences and implications. Often, the project has to make a guess as to the extent of the influence of the events on the course of the future. It often becomes clear during the construction of the story, when more and more details get clarified. The overall narrative is designed in a way that helps the participants identify with it and use it as a point of departure for the reflection on reality.
The most important requirement for a good alternate history is a good story.
Alternate history is not just a new concept or a new approach. It is a product. It is a story. And the quality of the story is essential to its success. It should be powerful, captivating, convincing, and inspiring. It should encourage reflection and inspiration, and it should be capable of generating cognitive dissonance, which is an experience that may result in new insights and more enhanced understanding of the complex processes of the modern world.
Alternate history is also a good story because it can help us understand the present better. It allows us to see things from a new perspective and to understand how different choices can lead to different consequences in the course of human evolution.
Making an alternate history can sometimes be difficult, frustrating or challenging. However, it is also a rewarding and creative process that can help us understand the world around us.
Alternate History Experience
An alternate history experience is an immersive and creative activity that allows participants to take part in a new story from a different perspective. It is about stepping into the minds of different characters and experiencing a different reality. The experience is a combination of the visual, auditory and participatory approach. Participants are immersed in an alternate scenario where they take on the role(s) of different characters. The scenarios differ in complexity, with a variation of tasks and activities, and with a varying level of difficulty.
Alternate history experiences can be used for different group sizes and different purposes. Examples could be:
Exploring history from different perspectives
Understanding the present better
Identifying and developing new talents
Identifying and developing potential leadership qualities
Exploring future prospects
Developing personal creativity
Encouraging cognitive flexibility
Understanding and dealing with complexity and conflicting aspects of reality
Developing resilience
Alternate history experience is an approach that allows participants to step into the shoes of different characters. They will be immersed in an alternate scenario where they will be engaged as a new and different person. Experiences can differ by the complexity of the scenarios, activities and tasks, and by an individual’s skills and capabilities and other personal factors, such as emotional state.
We are designing a number of different scenarios that can be used for a range of different group sizes and contexts. The scenarios can be adapted to suit the specific circumstances. We also offer different levels of complexity and interaction to cater to different needs and levels of experience and skills.

This year, 29,200 questionnaires were distributed to visitors to 778 events. All respondents were shown the text: What is the most positive thing about Gothenburg?
Respondents were asked to write down their thoughts. The findings from the 18th survey showed that the city centre is a popular meeting place for a wide variety of groups, all year round. Many respondents were from foreign business travellers, foreign tourists and groups coming on educational visits.
Even more often, respondents were from foreign tourists travelling on their own or in small groups, and from young people celebrating a farewell or a reunion.
The survey focused on visitors coming to or through Goteborg in conjunction with major events and events with 400 to 500 participants. The survey was carried out in November and December. The survey is intended to be comparable with the results of the VISITORS SURVEY carried out in 2013.
The results are based on around 2,000 completed questionnaires. The respondents were shown the text: What is the most positive/negative thing about Goteborg?
We would like to see more young people. We have fewer attractions during the winter months. We always have too much traffic. The people here are good listeners, and they like spending time together.
When we come here to work, we rarely spend any time outside. It is great to eat outdoors.

The survey was conducted to identify and analyse the strengths and weaknesses of Gothenburg through the eyes of visitors.

The overall aim of the survey is to identify the strengths and weaknesses of Gothenburg through the eyes of visitors, both during weekdays and at weekends.
The purpose is to use this information to set priorities for measures that promote meeting places and strengthen Gothenburg as a meeting place.
The survey will be carried out in 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018.
The survey is intended for visitors who travel to Gothenburg to participate in a major event that is organised by a group or association, or who are visiting Gothenburg for work or to give presentations.
This target group includes congresses and exhibitions, as well as groups of tourists and business travellers, sports teams, student groups and educational visits.
The survey is conducted jointly by Göteborg & Co, Kvinnobilden and Gothenburg Tourist & Convention Bureau.
The survey is carried out for two years, followed by a short evaluation round.
The results are published on the survey website and in the Gothenburg Visitor Report.
The survey includes 53 questions relating to demographics, activities, reasons for visiting, impressions of Gothenburg, wishes and comments.
The questions were developed on the basis of the results of previous surveys, on an international basis and in Gothenburg.
The survey includes questions related to the city centre as well as a series of questions about the visitors´ experiences in Gothenburg, as a whole.
The survey only covers the target group of congresses and exhibitions, trade fairs and groups of tourists with a specific purpose. Participants in the survey are respondents from major events coming to Gothenburg.
The sample comprises around 2,000 responses. Around 800 questionnaires are completed and the remaining questionnaires are not analysed.
The questionnaires are handed out at all major events in the city, in bars and restaurants and at various events at specific times.
The result shows which parts of Gothenburg that most visitors go to, and how often they visit. The questionnaire is anonymous.
Data is collected from the questionnaires. In addition, a series of questions are asked at the beginning of the survey to obtain an overall impression of Gothenburg, the experiences of visitors and the future plans for Gothenburg. The results are analysed and a summary is written in consultation with the survey partners, which will appear in the Gothenburg Visitor Report at the end of each year. The survey will be conducted every year up to and including 2020.
The survey was carried out as a pilot study in 2001 and the first full-scale survey was carried out in 2002.
The findings of the 2015 survey are available on the survey website. Visitors from Scandinavia are the most critical of Gothenburg as a destination.
The respondents were most satisfied with the availability of good food and beverages, a well-functioning infrastructure and the ability of the city to get around. The survey was carried at a time of major reconstruction in Stampen Square. After the completion of the project in 2016, future surveys will show whether people are more satisfied with the square.
The overall picture is similar in both year groups, where visitors are concerned, the results show that visitors, whether from Scandinavia or elsewhere, tend to be of the opinion that Gothenburg could be more attractive and should be more active.
The majority of visitors to Göteborg are tourists who visit Göteborg independently and in small groups.
The tourists who are most likely to provide negative feedback are from Scandinavia, mainly the UK, Germany and the Netherlands.
In all categories, except nightlife, the Scandinavian visitors are the most critical of their experience in Gothenburg and they are the most likely to give negative feedback.
People from northern Europe are generally more satisfied with their visit than visitors from other parts of Europe and other parts of the world.
Another difference is that visitors from Northern Europe often state that they are interested in visiting Gothenburg in the future.
The satisfaction with city restaurants and bars is similar for visitors from Scandinavia as well as those from other parts of the world.
Visitors from northern Europe are more satisfied with the public transport system, than visitors from other parts of Europe and visitors from southern Europe.
All visitors who visit Gothenburg as part of a major event are satisfied with the city centre, although different groups place different focus areas.
Visitors who come to Gothenburg on behalf of their employer or in connection with leisure activities are particularly satisfied with the availability of good food and beverages.
Gothenburg experiences a drop in satisfaction with the airport, which is often described as being small.
Visitors from northern Europe are the most satisfied with the airport and least satisfied with the accommodation options and cultural activities on offer.
There is a marked increase in the amount of activity carried out by visitors who travel with business associations.
Respondents who take an interest in sports are most interested in seeing a handball game, visiting a museum or attending an outdoor concert.
Visitors who travel on their own as a single group are interested in the arts and culture as well as shopping, while visitors who travel with business associations are focused on sports, business meetings and conferences.
In 2009, it was found that 41% of participants travelled to Gothenburg on their own without any kind of programme. When these participants were interviewed in 2010, around two thirds were satisfied with their stay in Gothenburg.
Visitors who travelled to Gothenburg on their own were mostly impressed with the location, the availability of good food and drinks and the number of events on offer in the city.

Dear reader, when writing this article I've started with 'Awakened' by Alpha Blond, a song I consider one of the most interesting song that I've ever listened in my life.
The song was a real inspiration for me, because is one of those song that have a meaning behind it and when listening to it is like a personal experience, but I won't go too much into details because I want to give you the chance to write your own experience
So here's the Lyrics
Love makes you blind,
Can’t see you’re dead inside
Just another dream,
Just another lie
Lost in a maze,
With your everyday life
What is a truth? What is a lie?
A lie is just another truth
Tell me a lie,
Make your day brighter
Just another dream
Tell me the truth,
What is the truth? What is the lie?
And I'll keep you blind
Blinded by love,
Eyes blinded by your light
Just another lie,
Better yet just another truth
Tell me the truth, but then…
Tell me a lie
(Tell me a lie)
Make your day brighter (Just tell me a lie)
Just a lie
Blinded by love (Just tell me a lie)
Eyes blinded by your light (Just tell me a lie)
Better yet just another truth (Just tell me a lie)
Just another truth (Just tell me a lie)
Tell me a lie, just tell me a lie
It's your choice, tell me a lie
Tell me a lie, and I'll keep you blind (Tell me a lie)
Tell me a lie, and I'll keep you blind
What is a truth? Tell me a lie (Just tell me a lie)
Tell me a lie, it’s your choice
(Just tell me a lie)
What is a truth? Just tell me a lie
Eyes blinded by your light (Tell me a lie)
You see, I still feel that this song is very inspiring.
The first time that I heard this song I immediately began to think of my own experiences, my own songs, and the way I was doing a lot of things, and also how I felt that my experiences with writing wasn't going in the way, that I wanted it to go.
The way that I usually write is more 'organized', since it is the first time that I want to try writing about 'a genre' (but in a different way, you'll see further).
It's interesting how our personal experiences can actually inspire something that can actually inspire many others, but I will focus more into writing about writing songs, because that's the aim of this section.
Another thing that inspired me, and I've already talked about in the article 'Melodies from the Mind' is the fact that I was trying to have a certain feeling for all the instruments that I use (but more on that later).
Now lets see what the song, and this whole thing, has taught me about writing a 'true song', something that is 'real', as in inspiring to so many, but most of all teaching you to really write a song from the heart, just like everything else should come from it.
1 - Start from something that has a 'meaning' to you, maybe a song that you actually think about, listen to, a melody that makes you think, a riff or any other thing.
As I said I had used a song that I have listened to many times, that actually makes me think of a special experience that I have with the song itself, and also makes me think about the way that I was actually writing my other songs.
2 - From that point on you just have to 'fill' the song with whatever you want.
I actually used a lot of 'stuff' from my memories, and from personal experiences, the experience of when I was younger, but also my current memories from working as a DJ and from the things that I hear, but most of all from the experiences that I've also listened to, and the way that I was 'inspired' by all of them.
3 - Write your 'feelings' into the song, the way that you think the song will actually make you feel, how you see others will react to the song, maybe even yourself after a while, or just even a time after you have finished, even when writing the second part (but also the way that you are listening to the song, after the song has been finished) and the way that will look back after a long time into the song and will be able even to understand the song, but also understand the 'meaning'.
4 - The way that you will see the song in a year, when listening to it you will see different things, you will think different things, you will experience better feelings.
5 - Write the real.
Writing a 'true song' actually means letting your listeners understand what you are feeling, and showing it into a certain feeling.

– Support multilingual students and their families; improve school climate; advance English-only policies; facilitate recruitment, retention, and hiring of multilingual and Spanish-speaking teachers; address racial/ethnic achievement gaps.
– Increase students’ content knowledge and language awareness through curriculum-based multilingual classroom activities.
– Increase cultural understanding, empathy and acceptance through activities that promote intercultural communication and comparisons of practices.
– Increase students’ linguistic, cultural, and ethnic affinity and improve self-esteem, identity formation, and classroom climate and performance.
7. Example: The Multilingual Classroom
– Content-based learning activities (Science, math, literacy, etc.)
– Games, interactive role plays, pairwork, small-group activities, and classroom discussions in language learners’ home languages, literacy activities in classroom languages, and the target language
– Interactive role plays: in the classroom, outside the classroom, and outside school
– Small-group and peer-to-peer collaboration
– Comparisons of practice to support identity formation and intercultural communication
– Language learning activities: listening, speaking, reading, and writing
– Language activities: alphabet knowledge (vocabulary, pronunciation, sentence construction)
– Literacy activities: reading comprehension, vocabulary expansion, grammar, and phonics
– Cultural and academic affinity, and sense of belonging
– Engaged learning and academic achievement
– Improved self esteem, resilience, and academic success
– Improved interethnic, cross-cultural, and cross-lingual communication and understanding
8. 4 Steps to a Multilingual Classroom
1. Establish supportive and cooperative community relationships with classroom partners and staff.
2. Develop culturally sensitive and appropriate multilingual classroom activities.
3. Evaluate, reflect, and refine multilingual practices for continuous improvement.
4. Connect your multilingual practices to curriculum, standards, and school goals.
– How can I establish cooperative and supportive relationships with parents, families, and staff, and with my classroom partners?
– How can I design and implement multilingual classroom activities that are culturally relevant and sensitive, and that promote intercultural communication and cross-ethnic learning, while reflecting district, state, or national policies relating to bilingual education and multilingual teaching?
– What resources do I need to support my multilingual classroom activities and to develop multilingual instructional approaches? How can I integrate the resources into my curriculum?
– How will I know that my multilingual classroom activities and approaches have been successful? What indicators will I use? How can I improve my practices and their effectiveness?
– How will I link my multilingual classroom activities and approaches to content, instructional goals, and assessment in order to meet local, state, or federal academic requirements?
– In what ways can support, guidance, and collaboration with colleagues help me to develop and implement more effective multilingual classroom activities? What kind of support do I need?
– What will I do to overcome challenges I face in establishing cooperative and supportive relationships with my classroom partners and their families, or in carrying out my multilingual teaching and classroom management strategies? How will I connect my practices with content, instructional goals, and assessment to achieve academic success?

Mario Suárez works with Teaching Tolerance’s International Education and Tolerance Center. He is the author of two Teaching Tolerance resources: Multilingual Education in the Mainstream Classroom and The Multilingual Classroom. Suárez has also published scholarly books and articles on bilingual education, language and minority education policy, and language and ethnic identity development. He recently edited Cross-Cultural Teaching and Learning: Global Perspectives and Practices in Education (Teachers College Press). He has been involved in professional development and curricula development for educators in the United States and abroad. Suárez has served as a bilingual coordinator for a large district in North Carolina, and he is an expert witness in minority language learning in U.S. districts nationwide. He has been an ESL teacher, a bilingual reading teacher for grade 2-5 students, and a teacher trainer at the elementary school and university levels. He also was a faculty member of the bilingual/multicultural education program in the School of Education at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

13. Teaching Tolerance:
About Teaching Tolerance Teaching Tolerance is a project of the Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC). Through research and educational resources, Teaching Tolerance helps teachers and schools ensure students receive a fair, accurate and inclusive curriculum. Teaching Tolerance works with educators to prevent prejudice, improve intergroup relations and promote equity as the foundation for students’ academic success. Teaching Tolerance is guided by the following purpose, vision and values: PURPOSE Teaching Tolerance believes that we live in a society filled with opportunity and diversity, and that creating caring relationships and civic participation can transform our children–and indeed, the world. VISION Teaching Tolerance believes that everyone has a role to play. It is our responsibility as adults to engage young people in opportunities for civil engagement. We believe that young people can make a difference in our world. MISSION Teaching Tolerance aims to help young people develop the knowledge, skills and disposition to act to advance the cause of inclusion and justice. VIRTUES Teaching Tolerance cultivates a community built on the values of integrity, fairness and respect for all people.
14. Teaching Tolerance Resources Teaching Tolerance produces a variety of materials designed to help educators meet the needs of the diverse population they serve. Our resources are available free of charge to all educators: Educational Articles: Feature articles on a wide range of issues that affect K-12 schools and educators. Free digital subscription includes monthly issues. Educational Films: Compelling films that cover a wide range of topics; also available free online. Educational Magazines: The award-winning School Family magazine is available free online and free in print to anyone who requests it Educational Research: Teaching Tolerance produces high-quality, research-based reports that summarize the current state of bilingual education and social justice in schools. Free Printed Materials: Teaching Tolerance’s catalog contains sample lesson plans, books, videos and other curriculum materials.

16. What is Teaching Tolerance?
17. About the SPLC The Southern Poverty Law Center is a nonprofit organization that combats intolerance, extremism and hate through education and litigation. Founded in 1971, the SPLC is internationally known for tracking and analyzing hate groups and other extremists, for providing training on hate group patterns and trends, and for filing lawsuits aimed at thwarting extremist activities. The Center has roots in the United Church of Christ and is governed by a National Board of Directors. The SPLC headquarters is in Montgomery, Ala.

A quick check on this one reveals a lot.
Firstly, you seem to have misunderstood what you have copied to the clipboard.
Clipboard: [91] Hello World ｣ ． ／ 〔 ･
This is correct. You entered the hexadecimal (base-16) digits for a single U+202b (SOFT HYPHEN) character to the clipboard. As that's all it is, when you paste into Notepad++ you get a stack of characters displayed as a single word, as it will assume you have typed that in. See?
Second, when you actually type it into Notepad++ it looks like this when using the character mapping of the Editor:
Clipboard: [91] Hello World ｣ ． ／ 〔
You can then choose Unicode, and it's all displayed as you would expect. The problem is that your choice of character encoding in Notepad++ is UTF-8. When you select that, Notepad++ thinks that each of these characters is the UTF-8 byte sequence that that character maps to; hence the output.
Lastly, I'll leave you with the fact that the following does work:
Clipboard: [72] Hello World ｣ ／
The character above is an acute ("´") accent ("´") over the second "o" ("o") and it just so happens that that character is encoded as U+006a when using UTF-8. As UTF-8 ignores the concept of bytes (which is why it's not called "UTF-7"), the character can also be displayed as "ó", which, on the web, is written as "`o`". (Yes; ASCII is just plain text.)
